PepperBell.Description: Bell peppers are vibrant, sweet peppers that come in colors like red, yellow, orange, and green.
PepperBell.Uses: Eaten raw in salads, grilled, or used in stir-fries, pizza toppings, and soups.
PepperBell.Benefits: Rich in vitamins A, C, and E, antioxidants, and fiber. Promotes eye health and boosts the immune system.
PepperBell.Interesting Fact: Red bell peppers have more vitamin C than an orange!

Potato.Description: A staple food worldwide, potatoes are underground tubers rich in carbohydrates.
Potato.Uses: Mashed, boiled, baked, fried (e.g., chips, fries), soups, and stews.
Potato.Benefits: Provides potassium, Vitamin C, and fiber. Helps regulate blood pressure when not deep-fried.
Potato.Interesting Fact: Potatoes were the first vegetable grown in space!

Tomato.Description: A juicy, red fruit commonly used as a vegetable in cooking.
Tomato.Uses: Used in sauces, salads, sandwiches, pizzas, and juices.
Tomato.Benefits: Rich in lycopene (a powerful antioxidant), Vitamin C, and potassium. May reduce cancer risk.
Tomato.Interesting Fact: Tomatoes were once believed to be poisonous!

Soybean.Description: A legume widely cultivated for its protein-rich beans.
Soybean.Uses: Used in soy milk, tofu, soy sauce, and meat substitutes.
Soybean.Benefits: High in protein, fiber, iron, and isoflavones; supports heart health and muscle growth.
Soybean.Interesting Fact: Soybeans fix nitrogen in the soil, improving soil fertility naturally.

Peach.Description: A sweet, juicy fruit with fuzzy skin and a large central seed.
Peach.Uses: Eaten fresh, in desserts, jams, and smoothies.
Peach.Benefits: High in Vitamin C, A, and antioxidants. Good for skin and digestion.
Peach.Interesting Fact: China is the world's largest producer of peaches.

Raspberry.Description: Red or black aggregate fruit made of many small drupelets.
Raspberry.Uses: Eaten fresh, in yogurts, desserts, jams, and teas.
Raspberry.Benefits: Rich in fiber, Vitamin C, and manganese. Supports metabolism and immune health.
Raspberry.Interesting Fact: Raspberries are not true berries—they’re aggregate fruits!

Grape.Description: Small, juicy berries that grow in clusters, varying in color.
Grape.Uses: Eaten raw, made into wine, raisins, jelly, and juice.
Grape.Benefits: Rich in antioxidants (resveratrol), supports heart health and reduces inflammation.
Grape.Interesting Fact: Grapes are one of the oldest cultivated crops—dating back over 6,000 years!

Strawberry.Description: A bright red, sweet fruit with tiny seeds on the surface.
Strawberry.Uses: Used in desserts, jams, smoothies, and salads.
Strawberry.Benefits: High in Vitamin C and antioxidants. Supports heart health and improves skin quality.
Strawberry.Interesting Fact: Strawberries are the only fruit with seeds on the outside!

Apple.Description: A crunchy, sweet or tart fruit available in many varieties.
Apple.Uses: Eaten fresh, in pies, cider, juices, and salads.
Apple.Benefits: Rich in fiber, Vitamin C, and plant compounds. Supports digestion and heart health.
Apple.Interesting Fact: An apple a day keeps the doctor away!

CornMaize.Description: A cereal plant with kernels used as grain, native to the Americas.
CornMaize.Uses: Cornmeal, popcorn, tortillas, corn oil, and animal feed.
CornMaize.Benefits: Source of fiber, B vitamins, and antioxidants like lutein and zeaxanthin (good for eyes).
CornMaize.Interesting Fact: Corn is in more than 4,000 grocery store items, from soda to ketchup.

Blueberry.Description: Small, round, blue-purple berries known for their sweetness and tang.
Blueberry.Uses: Eaten fresh or used in baking, jams, and smoothies.
Blueberry.Benefits: Among the highest in antioxidants. Supports brain function and heart health.
Blueberry.Interesting Fact: Native Americans used blueberries to dye fabrics and flavor meat.

CherryIncludingSour.Description: Small, red or purple stone fruit with a pit.
CherryIncludingSour.Uses: Fresh eating, pies, preserves, sauces, and juice.
CherryIncludingSour.Benefits: Anti-inflammatory, supports sleep (contains melatonin), and helps in muscle recovery.
CherryIncludingSour.Interesting Fact: Japan gifts thousands of cherry trees to Washington D.C. every year!
